data.title: Pewee Valley National Register Properties
data.meta_description: Pewee Valley, Ky. has two National Register Districts and a number of other buildings listed individually on the National Register of Historic Places.
data.text:
Pewee Valley National Register Properties and Historic Districts

Pewee Valley, Ky. has two National Register Districts and a number of other buildings listed individually on the National Register of Historic Places.

You will find a link to either the National Register Nomination or the Kentucky Heritage Council File on each of these properties under Related Links at the bottom of the individual property descriptions/histories on this website.

Individually-Listed Properties on the National Register of Historic Places in Pewee Valley

Individual National Register of Historic Places Listings

Not Included in Pewee Valley's Historic Register Districts

​1. William Alexander Smith House, 108 Mt. Mercy Drive, 1860

2. St. James Episcopal Church, 401 LaGrange Road, 1869

3. St. Aloysius Church, 201 Mt. Mercy Drive, 1914

4. Dr. Thomas C. Peebles House, 114 Maple Avenue, ca, 1870

5. George Miller House, 331 Central Avenue, ca. 1873

6. Van Horn-Ross House, 138 Rosswoods Drive, 1870

7. Tanglewood, 417 LaGrange Road, 1869

8. Bondurant-Hustin House, 104 Castlewood Drive, 1885

9. Joseph H. Ellis House, 320 Maple Avenue, ca. 1890

10. Forrester-Duvall House, 115 Old Forest Road, ca. 1908

11. "Sweet Shop," 301 LaGrange Road, 1905

12. The Confederate Cemetery, Maple Avenue near Floydsburg Road, est, 1904

13. The Locust, 6917 LaGrange Road

Individually Listed National Register Properties in Pewee Valley

National Register Properties in

Pewee Valley's Central Avenue Historic District

Central Avenue viewed through the gates of the Van Horne-Ross Estate. Photo by Kate Matthews. From the Fox Studio Movie Scrapbook at the Oldham County Historical Society.

​Central Avenue Historic District

​

1. James Foley House, 212 Mt. Mercy Drive, ca. 1875

2. Pewee Valley State Bank, 218 Mt. Mercy Drive, 1910 (now the Pewee Valley Woman's Club)

3. Woodside, 110 Central Avenue, ca. 1857

4. Bemersyde, 114 Central Avenue, ca. 1857

5. Sunnyside/Edgewood, 114 Edgewood Way, ca. 1858

6. Twigmore, 121 Peach Lane, 1923

7. Peace Farm, 100 Peace Lane, ca. 1880

8. Genevieve and Alfred Chesheir House, 120 Peace Lane, 1923

9. The Beeches, 125 Central Avenue, 1902

10. Pewee Valley Presbyterian Church, 119 Central Avenue, 1867

11. The Gables, 121 Central Avenue, 1895

12. Woodruff-Foley Brothers General Store, 220 Mt. Mercy Drive, ca. 1880 (now the Pewee Valley Vet)

13. W.N. Jurey's General Store, 200 Mt. Mercy Drive, 1912 (now the Little Colonel Playhouse)

Pewee Valley's Ashwood Avenue Historic District

Ashwood Avenue photograph by Kate Matthews. From the Fox Studio Movie Scrapbook at the Oldham County Historical Society.

Ashwood Avenue Historic District

2. Washburne-Swan House, 106 Ash Avenue, ca. 1905

3. William Logsdan House, 110 Ash Avenue, 1936

4. Carrie D. Coleman House, 112 Ash Avenue, ca. 1911

5. Truman-Nock House, 116 Ash Avenue, ca. 1890

6. Sherman and Corey Jurey Weatherly House, 111 Ash Avenue, ca. 1905

7. 115 Ash Avenue, ca. 1905

8. Mary Cleland House, 117 Ash Avenue, ca. 1915

​9. Charles Hoffman House, 121 Ash Avenue, ca. 1916

Ashwood Avenue Historic District Properties

Ashwood Avenue Historic District Nomination to the National Register of Historic Places

Your browser does not support viewing this document. Click here to download the document.

National Register & Other Historic Properties in

Pewee Valley's Wooldridge Avenue-LaGrange Road Area

The Avenue of Trees at The Locust. Photo by Kate Matthews. From the Fox Studio Movie Scrapbook at the Oldham County Historical Society.

Wooldridge-LaGrange Road Area

Only two of these historic homes (The Locust and the Wooldridge-Rose House) are on the National Register of Historic Places. Historic Pewee Valley, Inc. was unable to get this area designated as a National Historic Register District in 1989 due to opposition from property owners in the district, who feared it would limit future development opportunities. The Locust was individually nominated to the National Register in 1975 and the Wooldridge-Rose House in 2006.

1. Muir-Fetter House, 400 LaGrange Road, 1905 (see Judge Peter B. Muir and Edwin Bryant for information on this house)

2. Truman-Miller-Richards House, 500 LaGrange Road, ca. 1870

3. Wooldridge-Briggs House, 305 Wooldridge Avenue, ca. 1905

4. Wooldridge-Rose House, 315 Wooldridge Avenue, ca. 1905

5. The Locust, 6917 LaGrange Road, ca. 1800

6. Haywood House, 6901 LaGrange Road, ca. 1910

7. Rush-Gheens House, 13608 LaGrange Road, ca. 1871

8. Gheens-Becker House, LaGrange Road, ca. 1880
